div.head: TO THE MOST REVEREND FATHER IN GOD, GEORGE, by divine Providence, Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate, and Metropolitan of all England, and one of his MAIESTIES most Honourable Priuie Counsaile.
div.p:
AS Liuy of the Roman Republick:Liv. De • . 1. l. 1 Aut me Amor Negotij suscepti fallit, aut nulla vnquam Resp. nec Maior, nec Sanctior, nec bonis Exemplis Ditior fuit: so may I of the BOOKE of PSALMES, or I am too too farre transported with the Loue I beare to that Booke, or there is no Booke in holy Scripture more necessary to be intreated of, or which containeth more excellent Matter, or is more repleat with heauenly Passages. Euery Booke of holy Scripture, saith great Athanasius, hath that which is proper, and peculiar to it selfe,
Ath • na • . Epist. ad 〈◊〉
••
cellin, de Interp. Ps ••• .
〈◊〉 740. E •• . Comme •• .
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : but as for the Booke of Psalmes saith he, that is a Paradice, wherein i • planted euery Tree. So S. Basil: The Proph •••
haue Doctrine proper to themselues, the Bookes of History haue Matter peculiar to themselues, the Law her particular Forme of Teaching, and againe the Prouerbiall Bookes theirs,
Basil. Hom. in Princip. Ps. 1. p. 99. Edit. Basil. 1532.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : but the Booke of Psalmes compriseth in it the Profit of them all. So S. Chrysostom: Forasmuch as the Reading of Scripture hath much labour and paine, the Apostle here perswades thee not, to the Reading of the Histories, but to the Psalmes, that so by singing them, thou mayst not only delight thy Mind but beguile the Paine that would otherwise clog and cloy thee.
Chry. in ep. ad Coloss. c 3. Hom. 9. p. 74. b. Edit. Veron. 1529. Edit. SAVIL. Tom. 4. p. 138.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the Psalmes containe all. But what need wee goe to Greece for Testimonies in this case, hauing so ample Testimonie of his at hoame, for whom the Church of England may blesse the time that euer he was borne. I meane Reverend Hooker, who speaking of the Psalmes, VVhat is there necessary Mr. Hooker Eccles. Pol. l. 5. §. 37. saith he, for Man to know, which the Psalmes are not able to teach. They are to Beginners an easie and familiar Introduction, a mighty Augmentation of all Vertue, and Knowledge in such as are entred before, a strong Confirmation to the most perfect amongst others. Heroicall Magnanimity, exquisite
Iustice, graue Moderation, exact VVisdome, Repe •
tance vnfained, vnwearied Patience, the Mysteries of God, the Sufferings of Christ, the Terrors of VVrath; the Comforts of Grace, the VVorkes of Prouidence ouer the VVorld, and the promised Ioyes of that World which is to come, all Good necessarily to be either knowne, or done, or had, this one Celestiall Fountaine yeeldeth. Let there be any Griefe, or Disease incident to the Soule of Man, for which there is not in this Treasure-House a present comfortable Remedy at all times ready to be found. All which, hauing bene experimented in euery Age, hence it is that Dauids HARP hath euer had the preheminence aboue the whole Consort of those Heathen Musitians Simonides, Pindarus, Alcaeus, Horace, Catullus, and the rest; howsoeuerMy LORD of LOND. vpon Ionas. Lect. 27. p. 355. in Marg. & Barth. Scheraei Itinerar. in Psalt. Epist. Dodic.
Angelus Politianus, and Lazarus Bonamicus preferred Pindarus before him. Hence it was that Frederick the Second, late King of Denmarke, wrote a little Manuell with his owne Hand, of some of the choysest of them, which was his continuall Vade Mecum, as his most Excellent His MAIESTIES. Meditation vpon the LORDS Prayer. p. 96. MAIESTY, our SOVERAIGNE hath bene pleased to remember. Hence it was that long before,
ALFRED, great ALFRED, the Sam. Daniel Hist. of En • l. 1. p. 36. First lettered Prince we had in England, and by whose meanes, & incouragement, publique Schools had here, either their reviving or beginning, that ALFRED, I say, began to translate the Psalter into English, and well nigh had finished it, but thatM Fox his Act. and Mon. Edit. 4ae. p. 144 Col. 1. ex Hist. Guliel. de Regib. Angl • r.
Death which could by no means be intreated to spare, prevented him. In a word, hence it is that our Mother the CHVRCH of ENGLAND hath taken such speciall care that the Booke of Psalmes should be read ouer, every Moneth, and to be otherwise read then other Scripture, namely by interlocution, and with a mutuall returne of sentences from side to side, that so it might proue the more familiar to every of vs. To say nothing of thePolid. Virg. De Iuvent. l. 6. c. 2. Church of Rome which causeth them to be read ouer once a weeke, forasmuch as She stands vpon the Opus Operatum onely, and takes noAu •• te Novati •• i, apud qu •• Scriptura coelestes leguntur potius quàm intelligu • tur. Cyp. ad Novat. care at all to haue it interpreted to the People.

This and more then this being to be spoken of the BOOKE of PSALMES, I haue adventured among the Variety of Bookes now extant, to interpret the same vnto the
Church. Which though it hath as other Bookes of Holy Scripture store of Interpretours, yet in the Course that I follow, and in the Way that I take, I could neuer yet light, asmuch as vpon One. The way that I take, is the way of our English Church, and that Translation which Shee followeth in the Liturgie Shee vseth. Which Translation of Hers, howsoeuer it is not altogether as is the Hebrew, yet is it that which for the most part is correspondent with the Greeke, and our Church besides approouing it, as hitherto She hath, and still doth it well deserueth these paines to be taken therewith.

And indeed it will bee Paines to goe in this kinde through all. For being in all an Hundred and Fifty, and divided into Thirtie Daies according to the Daies of the Moneth, what will it bee to Comment on all? What to bring for every of them the Provision our Mat. 13. • 2. Saviour speakes of, New and Old. Vpon the First Eight, and the First Day of the Moneth, I haue here aduentured, as your GRACE may see. If they be acceptable to your GRACE, as I nothing doubt but they shall bee, in regard
the Author of them hath been so many wayes oblieged to your GRACE, (and to loue them on whom wee bestow Benefits is Nature, because in them wee behold the Effects of our Vertue) your GRACE hereafter may make him in Gods House no lesse then a MONETH, who is as yet but one DAY.

The Lord of Heauen blesse your GRACE and affoord you many good Dayes, and Moneths, and Yeeres amongst vs, that your GRACE reuiued, as it were, out of the Ashes of that Glorious Martyr, your Predecessor, CRANMER of blessed memory (who died before theAct & Mon. Edit. 4ae. p. 1569. and 1888. Gates of that Colledge, out of which, your GRACE is risen vnto vs) you may still with the help of that most Glorious MAIESTY in Heauen, and his Excellent MAIESTY here on Earth, stand against Thousands of the Church Malignant, and that whole Alphabeticall Rabble of Pontificious and FactiousM.C; N.D; C.E; I. E; H.I; I. R; L.R; S.R; W.R; and such like impetuous arring Snarlers. DOMINI Seru • s consumere nati. Priests and Jesuits, the Ban • of CHVRCH and COMMONWEALTH.

closer.signed:
Your GRACES in all
dutie.
JOHN DAY.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
COurteous Reader (for now that his MAIESTY hathHis MAIESTIES Meditat. vpon Mat. 27. v. 27, 28, 29 Advertisement to the Reader. styled thee so, thou art bound to make good that Epithite, and it is no small matter to be so styled by a King, especially by such a King) I am now about a Taske for thy behoofe, which if the Lord shall be pleased to prosper, it shall no whit repent thee, that thou hast procured thy selfe this Book, the First Fruits thereof. Bookes, I know, are Wares now a dayes nothing more common, and it is a World to see the seuerall Arguments of Bookes that are extant, but he of all Men speeds best, who procures himselfe such Books as may further his heauenly Knowledge here, and his eternall Happines hereafter. The Kingdome of Heauen Mat. 13.45. saith our Sauiour, is like vnto a Marchant man, seeking good Pearles, who when he had found one Pearle of great Price, he went and sold all that he had, and bought it. The trueth is, here's the Place, to buy and sell in this kind. The little Span of thy Life, is the whole Time that is allotted thee, to imploy thy Marchandise to that purpose. If thou now traffique while thou mayst, and hit vpon Pearles of great Price, I meane, Bookes of good Meditation, Happie, thrice Happie art thou, that euer thou wast
borne: If not: but thou neglectest the Time, and supposest to Morrow shall be as Yesterday, and the next Day to that, as were the Former Dayes already spent in much Iollity, beware it prooue not that Day, wherein the Lord shall come, andMat. 24.50. cut thee asunder and appoint thee thy Portion with the Hipocrites, there shall be weeping, and gnashing of Teeth.

2. Supposing, Beloued, thou fearest asmuch, and that thereupon thou art addicted to a Life more correspondent with thy Christian Vocation, then the ordinary Sort doe leade, and therefore frequentest the House of God, I meane the CHVRCH, especially at such times as Dauids Psalmes are there read, both at Morning, and Euening Prayer, I haue taken vpon me here to interprete those PSALMES, that as thou art willing to reade the same, though thou alwayes vnderstandest them not, in imitation of that ReligiousAct. 8.31. Eunuch, who in such sort read the Prophet Esay: so thou mayst as hee, haue an Interpreter in this case, though not a PHILIP, yet My Selfe, if so be the Lord be pleased, to make Me the Instrument to that purpose.

3. For to tell thee, good Reader, the Trueth, I am now I was borne Feb. 25. 1567. the Sunne for that Moneth being in Pisces, which puts me in minde of that of Folengius: Me esse Folengium cogito, Hominem nimirum natum Hyadum tempore (meaning November) idcircò ab Aquis illis non abhorrentem, quas Christus in Davide, vs{que} ad Animam suam intrasse queritur. lo. Bapt. Foleng. in Psalmos Epist. ad Niced. Fratrem. stricken in Yeeres, and more then Fiftie are already past, of thosePs. 90.10. Threescore and Tenne, that the Prophet Dauid allowes euen in common Account to the Dayes of our Age, and who knowes how farre short I shall come, or of those Yeeres, or of the Taske I haue begun, Cases which haue befalne many a Seruant of God, that hath bene imployed as I am. But if Death shall hereafter say of me (and none but
Death, I trust, shall so say)Luc. 14.30. This Man began to build, and was not able to finish:
Virg. Aeneid. l. 4.Exoriare aliquis nostris ex Ossibus Vltor,

Some one, or other, I trust, shall second me, and euen in despight of Death, perfourme the Worke I haue begunne. And though the Poet tell mee so peremptorily, Plant. Trinum. Act. 3 sc. Quomodò tu istuc. Nimium difficile est reperiri Amicum, ita vt, nomen CLVET, that it is impossible to finde a Friend, according to the significancy of that Name, yet seeing our Sauiour saith, that the Things which are Luc. 18.27. impossible with Men, are possible with God, I will dye, if I dye, in expectance of such a Friend; and as Iacob Gen. 48.5. said of Iosephs two Sonnes, Ephraim, and Manasses, that they should be his owne, as Ruben, and Simeon were: so my Friends Labours shall be mine, as this Ruben, and Simeon are; or to speake more properly, Christian Reader, they shall indeed be Thine. But of this, as God shall dispose, in the meane time let me infourme thee of many Particulars, concerning the Worke now in hand.

4. Hauing bene in Sacred I was made Minister by Dr Robinson Bishop of Carlile, in Queens Colledge Chappell in Oxford. Feb. 4. 1598. Orders well nigh these Twentie Yeeres, and improoued that poore Talent, which the Lord hath lent me, both abroad, and at hoame; J printed some Fiue yeeres since for my Parishioners in particular, and some other of my Friends, certaine SERMONS, and LECTVRES of diuerse and sundry Arguments, such as at that time J could imagine would be most behoouefull for them. Oftentimes after bethinking my Selfe what next of all to take in hand, that might bee suteable to those Beginnings, I resolued at length vpon the PSALMES,
as being most fit to be discoursed of, in regard of the dayly vse that all of vs make, or should make of that Booke of holy Scripture. Heereupon J beganne toI began on Christmas Day. Ao 1615. Lecture vpon them, and to interprete them one by one; but when J had Lectured vpon Fiue, which yet J scarcely finished in Two Yeares space, Suits, and Sicknesse so surprised me the next Two Yeares vnto those, that J could doe nothing at all in this kind. When I saw that in so many Yeeres my Motion was so slow, and that by this meanes J should come short of Saturne, the slowest of all the Planets, who yet inPlin. Nat. Hist. l. 2. c. 8.
Thirty Yeeres, perfourmes his Revolution, I resolued at the length vpon a speedier way, namely Reyn de Rom. Eccles. Idol. Epist. ad Com. Essex.
Manu & Scriptione, by Hand, and Hand-writing, to Comment on the Psalmes, and by Benefit of theImprimit ille Die, quantum non scribitur Anno. Act. and Mon. Edir. 4 p. 708. ex Aprutino. Presse to divulge them to the World, speaking to the Church by the Tongue of my Hand, euen as St Austen offered the Sacrifice of his Confessions vnto God, by theAug. Confess. l. 5. c. 1.
Hand of his Tongue. Which Course as it is the speedier, so hath it an other Benefite annexed with it besides, namely that by this meanes, the Candle that should haue bene otherwise, but vnder a Bushell of Auditors, is now on such aMat. 5.15. Candle-stick, as may easily giue light to all that are in the House, J meane the English visible Church.

5. In regard hereof I haue First made choice of that Translation, which the Selfe-same Church vseth in her dayly Deuotions vnto God. I know the last Translation is more agreeable vnto the Hebrew, theVid. Aug. de Doct Christ. l. 2. c. 11.
Originall of the Psalmes, whereunto in matter of Controuersie, wee are rather to referre our
Selues, howbeit since our Mother the Church notwithstanding that Translation hath retayned THIS still (whether in regard of our Cathedrall Churches that vse it singing wise, and Custome hath made it more familiar, which is as aDio Chrys. indeed compareth Customes to a KING, and Edicts to a Tyrant because we are subiect Voluntarily to the one, but vpon Constraint to the other. Chrys. Orat. 76.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Vid. Suid. in 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Nec quicquam impedit correctionem nisi Consuetudo cantantium. Aug. de Doct. Christ l. 2. c. 13.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Custom winneth such strength by time, that it is more firme then either Nature or Religion. N •
cet. p. 19.
Tyrant to bind fast; or in regard of the Septuagint so much commended by Aug. de Doct. Christ. l. 2. c. 15. & in Ps. 87. & de Consens. Evangel. l. 2. c. 66. & Quaest. sup. Gen qu. 169. S. Austen, and vsed by the Apostles themselues, out of which it was translated, certainely out of the Greeke, if that Greeke be not the Septuagint, asVid. Drusij Observat. l 6. c 9. & l 13. c. 12. some are of opinion; or in regard of the Translators themselues, who in the beginning of Queene ELIZABETHS Raigne translated that Bible, which was commonly called The Great Bible, and so in our Church Service Books the Title for the Psalmes, is this:Booke of Common Prayer. The Psalter or Psalmes of Dauid according to the Translation of the great Bible) since our Mother the CHVRCH, I say, notwithstanding that Translation hath retained THIS still, let vs followe our Mothers stepps, and seeing she giues vs these PSALMES as a dayly portion to feed vpon, eate wee our Meat without grudging. He is but a sorry Souldier that followes his Commander withMalus. Miles est qui Imperatorem gemens sequitur. Sen. Epist. l. 18. Ep. 108. finger in the Eye, and that Sonne that lets fall the Bread his Mother giues him, for it is but course to see to, and not so white as his fancy would haue, is like to make many hungry Meales, & to expose himself to the old Saying, Fast & welcome. I, but by these meanes will some say, all the Titles of the Psalmes will be omitted, which Titles are Scripture
to, and these Words will bee left out, Higaion, Selab, Neginoth, Nehtloth, Sheminith, Gittith, and the like. Indeed Omissions, if materiall, and no iust occasions thereof, are much to be misliked, and reference to be had to the Fountaine it selfe, which in many respects is most gratefull. Let mee goe no farther for Example then to the very Accidence, where we shall finde an Example of a Rule thus set downe,Rule of the Gerund in do. Caesar dando, subleuando, ignoscendo Gloriam adeptus est: a Speech cast oftentimes in Schollers T • eth by couetous Patrons, whenas they seek at 〈…〉 the way of Preferment: whereas had the words beene there set, as they are in the Author himselfe,Salust. Coniurat. Catilin. Caesar dando, sublevando, ignoscendo, Cato nihil largiendo, Gloriam adeptus est, they might easily haue answered those Cormorants, that it behooued Gentlemen to bee like Caesar, J meane for matter of Giuing and Bestowing, Schollers were to be like Cato rather, and according to Senecaes Senec. Epist. l. 1. ep. 11. Rule, to propose hîm their Example. But in earnest, what will they say to S. Pauls omission of a Thousand at a clapp in his Epistle to the1. Cor. 10.8. Corinthians, where he wrighteth 23 Thousand, whereas the Story Numb. 25.9. saith Foure and Twenty Thousand? What will they say toLuc. 11.4. S. Lukes Omission both of the Third and Seauenth Petition in the Lords Prayer, as also of the Conclusion, For thine is the Kingdome &c. which S. Mathew Mat. 6.13. hath? Or had they liued in those times would they haue petitioned against S. Lukes Gospell for wanting those Points. Doubtlesse had they done it, they would haue driuen S. Luke but to his old Profession to haue giuen them Physick for theColos. 4.14. Body,
seeing his Physick he gaue them for the Soul, wrought no better with them. To come vnto the purpose; Though these things here omitted, namely the Titles, and the Hebrew words, are not in this Translation, nor well could be in regard of Church-Service, yet are they in another. J meane that most exquisite Edition, as a most ExquisiteDr Hall of the Honour of the Married Clergy. l. 1. §. 26. Devine calls it. ButMr Th. Hutton his Answ. to the Minist. of Devm. and Corn. Part. 1. p. 133. & Part. 2. p. 205. others hereof haue spoken sufficiently long agoe.

6. Secondly, my chiefest ayme is at the true vnderstanding of each Psalme, as also of those Places that are more difficult then the rest. For we say not, as our Adversaries
Rhem. in 2. Pet. 3.16. say we doe, that the Scriptures are easie to vnderstand, much lesse that they may be expounded boldly of all the People, aswell Vnlearned, as Learned. No; Ignorance made those Notes, and Impudence maintaines them, as it doth many more besides boldly vented in that Booke. Wee to say that the Scriptures are so easie to vnderstand? Wee to say that they may be expounded boldly of all the People Learned and Vnlearned too? Quote the Authors, name the Men, or else be contented to bee branded hereafter for notorious Lyars in the highest degree. Jndeed weAug. de Doct. Christ. l. 2. c. 6. say with S. Austen, Honourably and profitably the Holy Ghost hath so tempered the sacred Scriptures that by the more easie places thereof, he hath taken order against Hunger, by the hard and more difficult places, he hath taken away all loathsomnesse. For nothing in a manner is picked out from those Obscurities, which in some other place may not be found to be spoken most plainely. And againe,Aug. lb. c. 9. Vid. Whit. de hoc loco Augustini. De Script. Contr. 1. Qu. 4. c. 4.
In those things that are plainely set downe in Holy Scripture, are all things found which contain Matter
of Faith, and the Manner of our Liues wee are to lead, namely, HOPE, and CHARITY. And most copiously in another place, Tanta est Christianarum profunditas literarum, &c. Aug. ep. 3. ad Volusian. Such is the depth of Sacred Scriptures, that dayly should I profit therein, if from my Childhood to Old Age, I should endeauour to learne them only with the greatest leasure that might be, with exceeding great study, and with a Wit answerable therevnto: not that wee attaine therein to those Things which are necessary to Saluation with so great difficulty, but when a Man hath learned thereby that Faith without which he can in no wise liue Godly and rightly, so many Things closed vp in so manifold Mysteries remaine to those that would profit therein, and such an Height of Wisdome lyeth hid not only in the Words they are deliuered in, but in the Things themselues that are to be vnderstood. Insomuch that it will happen to the most Elderly, the most Acute, the most desirous to learne, which the same S. Austen seemeth in this place to call Ecclesiasticus, SCRIPTVRE, not for hee tooke it to be Canonicall Scripture, but for it was wont to be read in the the Church to edification. Vid. Whit. de Script Contr. 1. Quaest. 1. c. 4. vnlesse by a slip of memory (often in the Fathers) he might thinke on the suddaine, that it was written in Ecclesiastes, or the Proverbs, for the Booke he doth not quote Or else hee might thinke at that time that Ecclesiasticus was written by Solomon. who afterwards altered that opinion. Whitak. Ib. Non sunt Canonici ad firmandum ea quae sunt Fidei: possunt tamen dici Canonici ad aed ficationem Fidelium, vtpote in Canone Bibliae ad hoc recepti & authorati. Caietan, in fine Comment. in Hist. Vet. Test. Whitak. loc. cit. Scripture hath in another place, Ecclus. 18.6. Vulg. when a Man hath done then he beginneth. Thus S. Austen, and thus wee, if any say more then this, it may be they haue relation to that ofEpiphan. Haer. 69. p. 376.
Epiphanius, Omnia sunt clara & lucida in Divina Scriptura. All things are cleere and bright that are contained in heauenly Scripture. And againe, interpreting as it were himselfe,Id. Haer. 76. p. 444 Vid. Whit de Script. Cont. 1. Quaest. 4. c. 4.
Omnia clara sunt in Diuina Scriptura his, qui ratiocinatione divinum Sermonem adire volunt. All in heauenly Scripture is cleere to them
who will reasonably take it in hand. But to returne where I left. When I say my cheefest Purpose is at the true Vnderstanding of each Psalme, as also of those Places that are more difficult then the Rest, it is not my meaning to arrogate to my selfe the true Vnderstanding of every Psalme, much lesse of every Passage contained therein: No; I say with Luther rather, wrighting on the selfe same Psalmes: Luth. Epist. ad Frid. Ducem Saxon. Praefix. Lib. Psalm. I here professe an Interpretation of the Psalmes, yet so I doe professe it, that I would haue no Man presume of me, which None yet of all the most holy and most learned Fathers could ever perfourme. Namely to Vnderstand and Teach the Psalmes in the right and true sence in every respect. It is enough to vnderstand some of them, and those some but in part neither, the Holy Ghost reserueth many things vnto himselfe, that thereby he might alwaies haue vs his Schollers. He only sheweth many things to allure vs to the reading of them, many things hee deliuereth thereby to stop our Mouthes, and as S. Austen speakes passing well, Nullus hominum ita locutu • est, vt in omnibus intelligeretur. Aug. de Trin. l 1. c. 3.
Neuer any man so spake as that he might truly be vnderstood of all men in all things. And therfore much more the Holy Ghost hath a certaine peculiar Vnderstanding of all his Words. And againe a little after, I knowe it is most impudent Boldnesse in any Man that shall dare to profess that he vnderstandeth in all points any one Booke of Scripture. Nay who dares presume that he roundly vnderstandeth one only Psalme.

7 Thirdly, in all Quotations of Holy Scriptures, the Psalmes excepted onely, for that by reading them in the Church so often, they are more familiar to vs in that Dialect, I shall wholy follow the last Translation,
vnlesse peradventure sometimes some occasion may bee giuen of a gratefull Remembrance of the Former. Nor shall this prejudice their Paines who haue by his Excellent MAIESTIES Princely Care beene imploied in the Latter, forasmuch as they themselues in their owne very Words commend the Former so much. We, Preface to the Reader Prefixed to the Bible Printed in the yeare. 1612. say they, are so farre of from condemning any of their Labours that trauailed before vs in this kinde, either in this Land or beyond Sea, either in K. HENRIES time, or K. EDWARDS (if there were any Translation, or Correction of a Translation in his time) or Q. ELIZABETHS of euer Renowned Memory, that we acknowledge them to haue been raysed vp of God, for the Building and Finishing of his Church, and that they deserue to be had of vs, and of Posterity in euerlasting remembrance. Aug. de Doct. Christ. l. 2. c. 12. Indeed as S. Austen tels vs, The diuersity of Translations is a Benefit to the Vnderstanding, if so be the Readers of holy Scriptures be not to to negligent. And therefore that Purgatories Triumph ouer Hell. p. 107 Goose that shamed not to publish in Print in the Yeare 1613. that Scripture with vs had beene scarce three Yeares a Mother, he doubtles was a wise one, but was he a Goose trow you, or a Gander? For his owne Mother Church of Rome was shee also Motherlesse & destitute of Scripture, before the Vulgar Translation? Or might it haue beene said to our Roman Catholikes,
Vid. Conc. Trid. April. 9. 1546. that that Scripture of theirs was not a Day old? Or be it it was S. Ieroms Translation (which they wil be neuer able to prooue) had their Catholike Roman Church, they so much brag of, no Scripture before that time, because they had not that Translation? S. Austens Words may bee
fitly here remembred,Aug. Ep. 6.
Quomodo ergò exierint de hoc laqueo alieno, sic exeant de suo: Answere one, and answere both.

8 Fourthly, my Practise hath beene to followe such Interpreters as haue gone before, Ancients and Moderne; Elder and Later; Old and Young. Nor am I dismaied with those Flowtes which Lud. Rouz. Problem. Miscellan. Problem. 17.
Ludovicus Rouzeus, a merry Gentleman it seemes, bestowes vpon Commentators out of Rablais. Hee questioning in a Booke of his to whom Commentators may be likened: Such kinde of men, saith he, may not vnfitly bee likened vnto Sheepe, the most simple, saith he, (set the Asse aside) of all Beasts whatsoeuer. For as those Commentators doe follow their first Leader quietly and peaceably without any more adoe, & tread in the self same Steps, euen so doe Sheep saith he, as Panurgus in Rablais hath taught vs in Pantagruels Nauigation. With that he tels the Story, & the Story was this: So it was that Panurgus hauing nothing else to driue away the time withall, bargained with a Sheep-master that with an whole Flocke of Sheep was in the selfe same Ship with him, for one of his Weathers, which when he had separated from the rest, he presentlyIt hath bene told me by an Atturney at the Law, that the like was practised of late, and an Action commenced thereupon in one of our Westminster Courts. cast it over boord. This when the rest of the Sheep beheld, they immediatly after their Fellow, and striuing with one an another which of them should ouer next, many of them in conclusion leapt into the Sea, insomuch that the Sheep-master himselfe with his Servants endeavouring to withhold the rest, and holding them by the Hornes, were driuen over boord with the violence of the Sheepe, and the Sheep, and they, duckt togither. Of two Similitudes
the Gentleman vseth, this is the better yet of both, and indeed the cleanlier, and Seneca noting this qualitie in Cattle, hath, I remember, these Words Nihil magis praestandum est, quàm ne Pecorum ritu sequamur Antecedentium Gregem, pergentes non quò eundum est, sed quo itur. There is nothing more to bee lookt vnto,Senec. de Vit. Beat. c. 1. saith he, then that we follow not them that went before vs, like Cattle in a Heard, going onwards, not whether wee should goe, but where the Way is troden before. But if so be this be so much to be lookt vnto, I for my part am content to be blinde, and if it be a Fault, I am wel pleased it should be mine. In Matters of Divinity, let themSee my LORD of CANTERB. vpon Jonas Lect. 25. §. 14. single themselues that list, I had rather bee the last in a Troope of good Interpreters, then be the Leader of a Band to Schisme and Singularity.

9 Fiftly, my Purpose is to set downe vnto thee the whole Psalme Word by Word; then, to bring it in a Briefe Analysis or Resolution, Verse by Verse, and afterwards, on every Verse to discourse more at large. This I take to be my best Course for the better exposing of the Psalmes to each Mans view, that wil throughly consider of them.Senec. de Vita Beat. c. 4. For as in Matter of War, one and the selfe same Army is sometimes spread out at length, sometimes drawne into a Ring, and yet hath one and the selfe same Strength, one & the selfe same Power, one and the selfe same Will: And as in Matter of Painting, Pictures, asSigna modò paruula fieri, & palmarem in minutiem contrabi, modò in immensum t • lli, & admirabilem in amplitudinem subleuari. Arnob. advers. Gent. l. 6. saith Arnobius (and we see it by Experience) are sometimes of the Bredth of the Palme of the Hand: sometimes of greater Bulck, and both represent the Party, to the better calling of
him to mind with every one that knows him: so may every Psalme to the Readers benefit, be thus contracted vpon occasion, and also bee explicated more at large. In which my Explications, my Intent and Purpose is, to haue a Regard vnto the Vnlettered aswell as to the Learned, hauing alwayes that of the Apostle before mine Eyes,Rom. 1.14. I am Debter both to the Greekes, and to the Barbarians, both to the Wise, and to the Vnwise. It was an Excellent Answer which Iacob gaue his Brother Esau when he would haue had him make that Superlatiue speed in journeying, himselfe did intend, My Lord knoweth Gen. 33.13. saith Iacob, that the Children are tender, and the Flocks, and Heards with yong are with me: and if Men should ouerdriue them one Day, all the Flock will die. Let my Lord, I pray thee, passe ouer before his Seruant, and I will lead on softly, according to the Cattell that goeth before me, and my Children be able to endure, vntill I come vnto my Lord vnto Seir. Right so, let Others take what Course they please, either altogether about the Hebrew Rootes, or altogether about Schoole-Points, or altogether about our Moderne Controuersies, or altogether about Postillers, and let let them be as Voluminous, and Copious, as Lorinus of late, I neither envy, nor admire them, they vse those many Talents they haue, and I this onely One. Wherefore as that vnfortunate, yet worthySt Thomas Overbury his Newes from the Court. Knight once spred it in the World for Newes, That to be SAVED, was the best Plot: so my Selfe am out of doubt, that the best Writing indeed, for a Man of my Coat is so to Write, that not so much the Vnderstanding, as the Will be bettered, not so much Knowledge,
as Life advaunced. And heerein I suppose I haue two such Abettors, as little Exception will be taken against, namely Iuntus, and Pareus: of whom the Former in an Epistle to Baro at Cambridge: When I looke, Si ad Rem specto, sic cogito, Nihil iam dici, quod non dictum sit prius: si ad Tempora haec nostra, ea esse in quibus Seruos Dei magis de Sanctimonia docenda, & Charitate accendenda, quàm de Quaestionibus laborare op • rteat. Fr. Iunius Epist. ad Baronem. Ms. saith he, vpon the Matter, I think with my selfe that Nothing can now be said, which hath not bene said already. If I looke on these our Times, I see them to be such, as that the Seruants of God, ought rather to bestowe their Labours in teaching Sanctimony of Life, and kindling Charity in their Auditors towards one an other, then in spending the Time about Questions. Pareus thus: The Cause of my Generall Silence Quod ad me, duas scito me habuisse Causas Silentij, at{que} etiamnum habere. Vnam General • m, quòd Aetate hac mea abuti non d • beo, nec volo ad contenoiosa, & semestria Scripta, quam totam dehinc (quantum mihi restabit) volente Domino, Scriptionibus exegeticis Sacrarum Scripturarum consecraui. Dauid Pareus Actor. Swalbacen. Part. 1. Collat. 4. saith he, is, for that I ought not, neither will I abuse this Age of mine, to spend it in Contentious Writings, and such as last but a while, which hereafter as long as it shall last, I haue consecrated Godwilling to such Writings, as shall onely expound Holy Scriptures. And againe a little after,Cuiusmodi Lucubrationibus me de Ecclesia longè melius mereri posse confido, qu • m si ad altercandum cum Adversarijs, quibus scio esse propositum nunquam tacere, nec cedere Veritati, Stylo, & Aetate abuterer. Pareus Ib.
By which kinde of Writings I shall farre better deserue of the Church, then if I should abuse both my Penne, and my Yeeres in wrangling with such Aduersaries as are fully purposed, I know, neither euer to hold their peace, nor to yeeld vnto the Trueth. His ExcellentHis MAIESTIES Medit. vpon the Lords Prayer. in the Preface. MAIESTY hath obserued the like in Bellarmine himselfe, who of late Yeeres hath giuen ouer (he saith) his Bickerings in Polemikes and Controuersies, wherein he was bred all his Life, and betaken himselfe now to set out a Short Meditation euery Yeere, sauing that he embellisheth euery
one of them with Two or Three Fabulous Miracles, which his Excellent MAIESTY well likeneth to those old Wiues Fables, whereof the Apostle St Paul speakes in his First1. Tim. 4.7. Epistle to Timothy. And it may be our Rhemists kept this good Decorum to, who making so many Polemicall Notes vpon other Books of Scripture, especially the New Testament, yet are nothing so plentifull vpon the Psalmes, whether it was, that they would keepe a good Decorum indeed, or which is more likely, for they had spent their whole Provision before, in their Notes on the New Testament. Many by giuing vnadvisedly, rashly, or foolishly Multi Patrimonia effuderunt inconsultè largiendo. Quid autem est stultius, quam quod libenter facias, curare vt id diutius facere non possis. Tull. Offic. l. 2. saith Tully, haue spent their whole Patrimonies. And what is more foolish, then that which a Man doth willingly, to take a Course, that he shall not be able to doe it any long while.

10. Sixtly, and lastly, my purpose is to quote vnto thee most exactly, what Testimony soeuer J shall haue occasion to bring, or out of the Fathers, or out of other Writers, whether Sacred, or Profane. A Labor which I could ease my selfe of, aswell as Others doe; but then I feare I should do thee wrong, & I professe I euer misliked that wilfull omission of Quotations, in Writers of our Age. It is true, the Ancients did it not, at leastwise so exactly, as Many doe now a dayes, but the Books then were not so many, & those that were, w • re better known, & perhaps there was not so much Iugling as is in this Age, eithe •
••
Adding or Detracting, or in plaine Belying the A • thor mentioned. Besides, they had not the Benefit of PRINTING which we in these dayes haue. A Benefit, which were it not abused,
as too-too commonly it is, might as truely bee stiled LEARNINGS-RIGHT-HAND, as any one thing whatsoeuer. And yet sometimes, because Some of the Ancients quoted not some things that they brought, but trusted their Memories too too much, what ouer-sights haue they made, and what mistakings haue past them in seuerall Places? I could instance in Diuerse, and in Matters of great Moment, but I had rather make mention of their Vertues, then of their Scapes. But as it is Carelesnesse in Some, so perhaps it is Envy in Others, not to acquaint their Readers with the Authors they haue profited by, but J would wish a true Scholler to beware of either, especially of Ingratitude, such as Macrobius is taxed with, who borrowing so much as he doth, saith myP. Crinitus de Honest. Discipl. l. 22. c. 4.
Author, neuer professeth to whom hee is behoulding. And yet I doubt not, but the exactest Man that is, may slip a Quotation sometimes. No Man I thinke in this kinde more exact, then that Doctor of most memorable worth, Dr REYNOLDS (famous for it to this Day) who hauing once notwithstanding omitted a Quotation, in hisD. Rey. Conf. c. 2. Diuis. 3. Edit. 1584. p. 110.
Conference with Mr Hart, about Sophocles, and Euripides, concerning the bringing in of the Persons of Women in their Tragedies, the One, GOOD; the Other, BAD; and my Selfe, for I was on a Time to make some vse thereof, desiring t •
• ow of him where I might reade that Passage, i •
• e Selfe same Paper that I sent, he returned mee wi •• his owne Hand, this Answer, euen in these very Words, which still I reserue & keepe by me, as an excellent Sparke of good esteeme.
div.q:
I did not quote the Place, because it came not then to my Memory, where I had read it. And yet I tooke the Persons, touching whom I had read it, to be Sophocles, and Euripides, because Aristotle
Arist. de Poet. c. 25.
Lib. de Poët. sayth of them, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : and indeed they two doe bring in Women, such (in the Tragedyes which are extant) the One, Good, the Other, Bad. But since, I haue read it of Philoxenus, and Sophocles, in Plutarch as I thinke; In whom, because I remember not where it is neither: I send you a Booke, which mooueth me to thinke it is in him (sith sure it is not in Laertius, vnlesse I haue maruailously forgotten) by conferring the Title with p. 702.
div.p:
Thus far, that worthy Doctour, & so copiously of that Point, of which Others would haue thought they had said sufficiently, if they had said his first words only, I did not quote the Place, because it came not then to my Memory. But
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Apertae. Erasm. Adag. Chil. 2ae. Cent. 7. Adag. 41 Candidae semper Musarum Ianuae. Indignation, & Disdaine neuer garded the Muses Gates. Ingresse, & Egresse, & Regresse at wil, was alwayes free for those that were not vnwilling to learne. As for those that on the contrary mislike this kinde of Writing, and stile it rather an Hotch-podge, then a Writing indeed, let them for me, inioy that humor, & imitate in their Writings, Epicurus if th •• please, who is Montaigne his Essays. l. 1. c. 25. said in 300. Volumes left behinde him, not to haue made vse of any one Allegation. J for my part doe not think Wrighters are giuen vs to so smal vse. Lipsius me thought, spake well, had he neuer spoken worse,Lips. Polit. Ep. ad Lect. Inopinatum
quoddam styli genus institaimus: in quo verè possim dicere, omnia nostra esse & nihil: I haue framed my selfe in this Booke, to an vnwonted kind of Stile, wherein J may truly say, that both all is mine, and yet nothing at all. And againe; Id. ad. Libr. Polit. brevib. Notis. Lapides, & Ligna ab alijs accipio: Aedificij tamen exstructio, & Forma tota nostra. Architectus ego sum, sed materiam variè vndi{que} conduxi. Nec Aranearum sanè textus ideò melior, quia ex se fila gignunt: nec noster vilior, quia ex alienis libamus ut Apes. Stone, and Wood I haue of Others, yet the Building of the Edifice, and Forme thereof is wholly mine owne. Nor is the weauing of Spiders to bee therefore accounted better, for that they bring all from their owne Bowels: nor is ours to be esteemed worse, for that like Bees wee gather the Iuyce of severall Flowres. In a Word I will conclude this Point with that of oldChaucer of the Astrolabe.
Chaucer, to lytel Lowys his Sonne, when he wrote him a Tract of the Astrolabe: Consydre the well that I ne vsurpe not to haue founden this werke off my Laboure, or off mine Engin. I nam but a
Leude, that is, Vnlearned, not as the Word now is vsed for Wicked.
leude Compylatour of the Laboure of old Astrologiens, and haue it translated in myn Englysh onely for thy Doctrine: and with this Swerd shal I slene Enuy.

11. And thus good Reader haue I now acquainted thee with my whole Proiect in this kinde. Thou seest what I haue intended, and purposed for thy sake. That as yet I haue gone no farther with thee then one Dayes Iourney, J meane, but to the Eight Psalme, it is, for as yet I know not how thou wilt accept of my Company; and my Sauiour hathLuc. 24.28. taught me not to ouer-intrude my selfe, though it might be
to good purpose; but if my Company be pleasing to thee, and thou canst be contented with so meane a Guide, I shall not faile God-willing, to goe with thee quite through. It is my Desire so to doe, it is the vttermost of my Wishes; and as Naomi said to Ruth, Ruth. 3.18. Sit still my Daughter, vntill thou know how the Matter will fall: for the Man will not be in rest, vntill he haue finished the Thing this Day: So assure thy selfe, Christian Reader, I shall affoord my Selfe no Rest, no Rest to speake of, vntill I haue finished this Thing, I cannot say [THIS DAY] that indeed is impossible, but this will I say vnto thee, though it may seeme very improbable, that not a DAY shall ouer my Head, (if God, and Necessity let me not) but shall haue at least a Line, a Passage to that purpose. Apelles his Plin. Nat. Hist. l. 35. c. 10. NVLLA DIES SINE LINEA, shall be my dayly Memorandum till all be done.

12. Pliny speaking of Bees: Before that Beanes, Ante Faba • florentes non l. exeunt ad Opera & Labores, nullus{que} cum per Coelum licuit ocio perit Dies. Plin. Nat. Hist. l. 11. c. 6. saith he, begin to bloome, they settle not themselues to any worke, or Labour, but thence forward, they loose not a Day, neither play they one iote, if the Weather be faire, and will permit. Surely, Beloued, though with mee the Beanes doe not bloome, yet the Flourishing of myEccles. 12.5. ALMOND TREE puts me in mind, that now the time is to work indeed, & from hence forward what remaineth, but that I become a Bee, nay more then a Bee, by not loosing so much as a Day, be the Weather Faire, or Foule. The rather for it cannot now be long, but that I must put off, as S. Peter 2. Pet. 1.14. speaketh, this my Tabernacle, two Peales already hauing rung to that EVEN-SONG. Wherefore as Thespesius in Plutarch,
when he Plut. de bis qui serò a Numine puniuntur. sent to the Oracle to know Whether the rest of his Life should be better, then that which went before: receiued an Answere, that it should be much better, but after he should be dead, whereupon he dyed (they say) and as they say, revived againe, and became much more Iust towards his Neighbours, more Religious towards God, more Grieuous to the common Enemy, more Faithful to his Friends then euer in his Life before: euen so of late Yeeres, hauing bene twice so neere Death, as I haue, I thanke God, what remaineth but I turne a new Leafe, and by going forwards in this kind, I become more Religious towards God, more Officious to Gods Children, more Obnoxious to his Enemies, more Faithful to my Friends, by not suffering minePs. 132.4. Eyes to sleepe, nor mine Eye lids to slumber, neither the Temples of my Head to take any rest, vntill I haue fully finished this Worke, and brought it to that Perfection, that though it prooue not a Temple it self an Habitation for the Mighty God of Iacob, yet it may prooue a Booke, a Volume for that Temple, or rather a Booke, and Volume for such as the Apostle S. Paul, 2. Cor. 6.16. stileth, The Temple of the Liuing God.

13 And the Premisses I may now professe the rather, and bee the better able to perfourme, seeing in regard of two mayn CROSSES that haue befalne me of late (Crosses, I hope, to great good purpose, and by consequence, great BLESSINGS) I cannot altogether say as Pope Innocent did, who wrighting vpon the Poenitentiall Psalmes, Ne inter occupationes multiplices, & solicitudines vehementes, quas non solùm ex cura Regiminis, verum etiam ex malitia Tempogis patior vltra vires quasi totus abs •• bear Profundo: libenter alias • orulas mibifurar &c. Innocent in 7. 〈◊〉
• oenit. Pro • m. professeth hee was faine to steale some Houres to performe that Worke
of his, his Affaires were so many, and his Cares in Gouernment so great. Concerning Cares in Gouernment, I am likely enough to be well rid of. Publike Functions in the opinion of my best PHISITIANS are not for my Diet. I cannot say asFrontin. Stratagem. l. 4. c. 7. Scipio did, nay I may say quite contrary, Bellatorem me Mater, non Imperatorem peperit: howbeit for stealing of Houres, therein am I likely to bee more true then Pope Innocent. J need not steale them, nay I may for thy behoofe bee as Bookish as the Day is long; and I now knowe at length the Pretiousnesse of Time, nor shall it ever repent mee that after so many Yeeres spent in this most famous VNIVERSITY, I can paralell Socrates his VNVM SCIO, with the knowledge of my owne NAME. And vpon this Confidence I proceed. Nether regard J theTriall of Wits. c. 1. Triall of Wits that wisheth every Man to abstaine from wrighting any Bookes as soone as he is past Fifty; as his Excellent MAIESTY hath obserued (I suppose to the Author of that Books Disgrace, His MAIESTIES Meditation vpon the LORDS Prayer. Preface. who himselfe past Fifty Yeares hath left his Subiects such MONVMENTS, and many more may he leaue vs) No; J prefer before that Triall, the Triall of Scripture, which speaking of the Righteous, sheweth, thatPs. 92.13. Tremel.
Adhuc abundabunt in Canitie, They shall bring forth more Fruit in their Age, and shall be fat and wel liking. Jf Hippocrates in his Phisitians saith that worthy lateMr. Hales his Sermon vpon Easter Tuesday. 1617. concerning the Abuses of obscure and diff. places of holy Scr. &c. p. 11. Professor of the Greeke amongst vs, required these two Things, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , great Industry and long Experience, the One, as Tyllage to sowe the Seed, the Other, as Time & Season of the Yeare to bring it to maturity: then certainely
by so much the more are those two required in the spirituall Phisitian, by how much hee is the Phisitian to a more excellent part. A great part of the Troubles of the Church of England, Mr Gosson his Trumpet of Warre. saith a good Devine, hath sprung out of greene heads, that haue much busied themselues about the state of Bishops. These are young Gartio quis{que} duas postquam scit iungere partes, Sic stat, sic loquitur, velut omnes noverit Artes. Ioan. Sarisb. de Nugis Curiat. l. 7. c. 12.
Cockerels, that haue learned to clap only their feeble Wings, and to Crowe vpon the Roost in time of Peace, but when Religion is in danger, they dare not come into the Cock-pit to try Masteries for Religion, as Mr JEWEL, and many other good BISHOPS haue done, that are gone to God. But now, Christian Reader, by this time, I imagine, thou art desirous to see the Premisses perfourmed, and to betake thy selfe to the First Psalme. Howbeit for in the Title of my Booke (the Title that drew thee to buy it) there is mention both of Psalmes, as also of the Psalter, a word or two of both these Words before thou goest any farther, perhaps it may yeeld thee good contentment in this thy intended iourney.

Illyr. Clau. Script.14 First, for the Word PSALME, Psallere, saith Illyricus, is originally a Greeke word, & properly signifieth Pulsando citharam, melodiam excitare, by striking of the Harp to make a melodious sound. But forasmuch as in times past, the Israelites, saith hee, did sing to the sound of the Harp certaine Verses withall, not only in the Temple where most commonly it was vsed, but also in private: hence it came to passe that sacred Ditties in that kinde were cald by the name of PSALMES. Now if we consult with S. Paul in his Epistle to the Colossians, he will there tell vs of Psalmes & Hymnes, and Spirituall Songs. Let the word of Christ,
Colos. 3.16. saith he, dwell in you richly in all wisdome, teaching and admonishing one another in Psalmes, and Hymns, and Spirituall Songs, singing with grace in your hearts to the Lord. Jt is in the Originall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .Zanch. in Coloss. 3.16. Zanchius wrighting on that place, Betweene these three words [Psalmos, Hymnos, Odas] Psalmes, Hymnes, and Spirituall Songs, saith he, diverse men put a diverse difference. He alleageth first of all S. Ierom, but somewhat to sparingly, for Ierom in the place alleaged hath the words more at large. First, those are Hymnes,
Hieron. Comment. in Ephes. l. 3. , saith S. Ierom, which declare theFortitudinem & Maiestatem Dei. Greatnes and Maiestie of God, and set out to the admiration of Men his Benefits and Wonders. Psalmes properly appertaine to the Moral part of Man, that by the instrument of the Body wee may haue perfect knowledge what to doe, what to shun. But hee that discourseth of superior things, saith S. Ierom, & of the Harmony of the World, and of the order and concord of the Creatures therein contained, he it is that sings a spirituall Song. Or in regard of the Simple, saith he, to speake somewhat more plainely what my meaning is, A Psalme is referred to the Body, an Hymne, or Song, vnto the Mind, and therefore with the Minde, rather then with the Voice, we ought, Et Canere, & Psallere, & Laudare Dominum, to sing Songs, and Psalmes, and to Praise the Lord. Others, Zanch. vbi supra. saith Zanchius, by Psalmes vnderstand onely Davids Psalmes; by Hymnes other Songs here and there in the Scriptures, as the Song of Moses, of Deborah, of Esay, of Daniel; and by Spirituall Songs, they meane such as are composed by Godly Men, to expresse thereby Gods Benefits vnto vs. But
the more Learned, saith hee, now adaies doe thus distinguish them, Psalmes are Songs consisting of diverse Arguments, so that a Psalme is a generall name to Prayers for Benefits to be receaued, Prayers against Adversities, Prayers of Comfort, & so forth. Hymnes be such as properly set forth the Praises of God, and therevpon S. Chrysostom,Gracè 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Chrys. in Coloss. 4. Hom. 9
Hymnus Psalmo sanctior, A Hymne is more Divine then is a Psalme. But Songs be peculiar Hymnes artificially made, and after a more Maiestical forme then ordinary, & they are therefore called Spirituall, for that they proceed from the holy Spirit wherewith they that sing them are repleat, & he alleageth for proofe hereof a place of the Apostle to the Ephesians. Ephes. 5.19.

15 Concerning the Word PSALTER, Jt is, Hieron. Pro
• m. in Comment. Psal. saith S. Ierom originally a Greeke Word, and in Latine it is called Organum, an Jnstrument, that which the Hebrews cal NEBEL: and Psalmus, saith he, hath his name either of Psalterium, or else of Psallere to sing. And from NEBEL in the Hebrew comes the Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and from thence the Latine Nablium, whereof Ovid the Poet speaking,
Ovid. de Art. l. 3. Disce etiam duplici genialia vertere palma
Nablia, conveniant dulcibus illa modis. This Booke,
Doway Bible. Prooemiall Annot. vpon the Psalmes. p. 13. say our Rhemists, hath his Name of the Instrument called Psalter, which hath tenne strings signifying the Tenne Commandements, & is made in forme as S. Ierom, and S. Bede suppose, of the Greeke Letter Δ Delta, because as that Instrument rendreth sound from aboue, so wee should attend to heauenly Vertues which come from aboue. Jndeed P. Lumbard out of whome
they haue that concerning the Ten Commandements, seemeth to make Psalterium, and Decachordum, all one, and thereforeP. Lomb. Se •• . l. 3. dist. 37. saith, Habet Decalogus decem Praecepta, quae sunt decachordum Psalterium, in regard whereof they here say, The Instrument called Psalter which hath Tenne Strings, but had they consulted withDrusius Observat. l. 10. c. 2. Drusius he would haue told them that the Psalter, and the Instrument with Tenne Strings were two diverse Instruments which hee prooueth not onely by the testimonie of the Iewes, but by the Nintie and Second Psalme, where it is said,Vulg. In decachordo, Psalterio. P ••
1.4.
Super Decachordo & super Psalterio. But whatsoeuer the Originall is, certaine it is that the word Psalter is now taken for all those Psalmes that are comprehended in the number of an Hundred & Fifty, some of them being of Davids making, some of them made by some others, though Ambr. in Ps. 45. & 47. Chrys Prooem. in Ps. Aug. de Civ. Dei l. 17. c. 14. some are of opinion that all and every of them were made by Dauid. But whether this were so or no, as it is vncertaine, so sure and certaine it is, that they were all of them made to God, not to Abraham, Isaac or Iacob, not to Angell or Archangell, but only vnto God. It may be a challenge sufficient vnto them all (said that all-sufficient My LORD of LONDON vpon Ionas Lect. 16. Lecturer, now a worthy Bishop of our Church) that in so many Prayers of both ancient and righteous Patriarkes, Prophets, Iudges, Kings, registred in the Booke of God, and in an Hundred and Fifty Psalmes, an hundred whereof at least are Prayers & Supplications, and in all the devout requests that the Apostles of Christ and other his Disciples sent into heauen, (if they take the penne of a writer, and note from the beginning of Genesis to the end of the Revelation) they cannot finde
one directed to Cherub or Seraphim, Gabriel, or Raphael, Abraham, or Moses, or Iohn Baptist after his death, or any other Creature in heauen or earth, saue only to the Lord or his Annointed.

16 The greater wrong our Adversaries doe, & the more blasphemous they are against that LORD, and against his ANNOINTED, that haue suffered a Psalter to goe forth in imitation of this, and haue named itImprinted by Iohn Cawood Ano D. 1555. Vid. Act and Mon. Edit. 4.a p. 1598. OVR LADIES PSALTER. And how our Ladies Psalter? Was it trow you their meaning that the Blessed Virgin made that Psalter, as Dauid made this? No; but see their Blasphemy, see, and admire. They haue in every Psalme, nay almost in every Verse changed the Name of the LORD, & placed insteed thereof the name of Lady, every Prayer to the Lord therein, they haue made it a Praier to our Lady, every Praise and Thankesgiuing in it, they haue attributed it to our Lady. Which had they done only in former times when all was overwhelmed with that Aegyptian Darknesse of Rome, I had held my Tongue, asEsther. 7.4. speakes, Q. Esther, although the Enemie could not haue countervailed the King of Kings this Dammage, but now in this Sunne-shine of the Gospell that they shouldPsalterium Marie Ingolstad. recusum Ao 1593. Vid. Acta Colloq. Swalbacens. Collat. 3. p. 33. Reprint such a Booke, and set it to sale among their Followers to be said by them day by day with Beatus Vir qui intelligit Nomen tuum Maria Virgo &c. Blessed is the Man which vnderstandeth thy Name O Virgin Mary, &c. alluding to the First Psalme; And Quare fremuerunt Inimici nostri & adversum nos meditati sunt inania? Protegat nos Dextra tua Mater Dei, &c. Why doe our Enemies fret & imagine vain
things against vs? Let thy right hand defend vs O Mother of God, &c. alluding to the Second; And, Domina quid multiplicati sunt qui tribulant me &c. Why are they so many, O Lady, that trouble me, &c. alluding to the Third; And, Cum invocarem exaudisti me Domina, &c. When I called to thee thou heardest me, O Lady, &c. alluding to the Fourth; And, Verba mea auribus percipe Domina, &c. Heare my words O Lady, &c. alluding to the Fift; And, Domina ne in furore Dei sinas corripi me, ne{que} in ira eius iudicari, &c. O Lady, let me not be rebuked in Gods indignation, nether be chastned in his displeasure, &c. alluding to the Sixt; And, Domina mea in te speraui, &c. O my Lady, in thee doe I put my trust, &c. alluding to the Seauenth; And, Confitebor tibi Domina in toto Corde meo, &c. J wil giue thanks to thee, O Lady, with my whole heart, &c. alluding to the Eight, and so along to the Hundred and Fifty Psalme (for so long the Chymes goe) that is too too abhominable euen to be read, but to be practised, in this sort, what is Idolatry, if not this? What is Blasphemy, if this be not? Is this the fruit of the Apostles Doctrine, that wee are fully compleat inRom. 12.5. Ephes. 3.19. Colon. 1.19 Christ? Is this the Dignity, Glory, Authority, Reverence, and Service that is in this kind onely done vnto the Lord? Is this the meaning of their Hyperdalîa, which, they say, they only giue her, namely to aske of her to saue our Soules; to giue vs Peace; to grant Grace; to comfort the Desperate; to loofe our Captivity; to release our Sinnes; to deliuer vs from Sathan; to Bring vs to Heauen; all which they doe in those Psalmes, and greater Benefits then which; we cannot
aske at Gods hands? Is not this Latrîa in the highest degree, which sometimes in their better mood they will affoord forsooth to God onely, onely to God? I knowe they father this Booke on their Seraphicall DoctourBonavent. Tom. 6. p. 478. Bonaventure, and in Bonaventures Works haue they now Printed it, in as faire a Character as faire may bee, but I am of their opinion that verily thinke Bonaventure is wrongd therein, and that hee was so far from making such a desperate adventure as this, as that he hath in those Works that are vndoubtedly his, divers Passages to the contrary. For farther satisfaction in this point, I referre thee to that which Pezel. Refut. Catech. Iesuit. p. 105. Edit. Ao D. 1599.
Pezelius hath said hereof. In the meane time for we are now in an Argument concerning our Ladies Psalter, let me acquaint thee with a Story which I haue read in Sr Thomas Moore, and so much the rather, for it is Sr. Th. Moores Workes in English, printed in Folio. 1557. His Works in Lat. & in 8o printed at Basil, 1563. and His Works in Latine, and in Folio printed at Lovain. 1566. neither in his English Workes printed at home, nor in his Latine Printed abroad, either at Basil, or at Louaine. And I am perswaded omitted of purpose by the Louanists in their Edition, who, had it made against vs but halfe so much as it doth against themselues, they would haue found out the Copy, and haue printed it well enough. The Story is this.

17. There wasAn old printed Booke, whose Title is, Epistolae aliquot Eruditorum, nunquam antehac excusae, wherein are contained Eight Epistles. The last of all, which is an Epistle of Sr Thomas Moores, to a certaine Monke vnnamed, is the Epistle here quoted, and borrowed of my worthy Friend, Mr Henry Iackson, Fellow of Corpus Christi Colledge in Oxford. Which Epistle, as they haue left out: so haue they left out an other in the Louaine Edition, of Sr Thomas Moores, to Martinus Dorpius, in defence of Erasmus his Mori • , but that as hap is, is in the Basile Edition, beginning p. 365. and reacheth to p. 454. saith he, at Couentry a Fryar of the number of those Franciscans, which were not as
yet refourmed to the Rule of S. Francis. This Man preached in the City, in the Suburbs, in the Townes & Villages thereabouts, thatQuicun{que} Psalterium Beatae Virginis oraret quotidiè, nunquam posse da •• ari. He that should pray the whole Psalter of the Blessed Virgin quite ouer euery Day, could neuer be damned. This was no sooner deliuered, but it was as easily heard, and as readily beleeued, for that it shewed so easie a way to Heauen. The Pastor of that Place, an honest, and learned man, though for his owne part he knew well ynough, that it was but foolishly spoken, yet he dissembled awhile, supposing that no Harme would ensue thereupon, and that the People, the more addicted they were to the worship of the Blessed Virgin, the more Religious they would bee. HowbeitAt vbi tandem recogn • scens Ovile, depreh • ndit ea Scabi • vehementer infectum Gregem, pessimum quem{que} in illo Psalterio maximè Religiosum esse. afterwards overlooking his Sheepfold, & finding his Flocke so tainted with that sore, that the very worst in all his Parish, were most addicted to that Psalter vpon no other minde & purpose, then to dare to doe any thing, and that there was no doubt at all, but they should haue Heauen, which so graue an Author as the Fryar, falne as it were from Heauen vnto them, so faithfully promised, then at length he began to admonish his People, that they should not trust too much to the saying of that Psalter, though say it they should no lesse then Ten times a Day. Certainely that they did well, who said it well ouer, so that they said it not vpon that Confidence, wherewithall others had now begunne, otherwise much better it was to omit those Prayers altogether, so they would omit those Crimes to, which vnder the Patronage of those Prayers they did so confidently commit. This when once he had spoken to
them out of the Pulpit, strange it was how waspish they were, they chalenge him for his Words, they hisse at him, they driue him out of their Company, and defame him as an Enemy to the Virgin Mary. The Fryar an other Day vp to the Pulpit with all speed, and to vexe Mr Parson the more, begins with this Theame, Dignare me laudare te Virgo sacrata, da mihi virtutem contra Hostes tuos. Vouchsafe me, O sacred Virgin, to sound forth thy Praise, affoord me power against thy Adversaries. For they say, a certaine Scot did vse the selfe same Theame, being to dispute at Paris of the VIRGINS Immaculate Conception, Qui Luteciam in momento delatum periclitante scilicet alioqui beata Virgine, milli • Passuum plusquam trecanta menti
•• tur. who they say (with lye & all) was brought in a Moment to Paris, more then 300 Miles, the Blessed Virgin otherwise in great extremity of daunger. But what need many Words, the Short, and the Long was this, the Fryar easily perswaded those that were willing ynough to beleeue, that their Pastor was a Foole, yea and a Wicked Man to. Now while all was in this hurly burly, it so fell out, that my selfe, saith Sr Thomas, had occasion to goe to Couentry, to see a Sister of mine there. I scarce was allighted from my Horse, but to me the Question was presently proposed, Whether he that said ouer the Blessed Virgins Psalter euery Day, could possibly bee damned. I fell a laughing at a Question so ridiculous, but presently was J told, that it was no laughing matter, for there was in Towne a most holy Fryar, and one most learned to, that had preached that such an one could not be damned. I contemned the whole Matter, as little appertaining vnto me, whether so, or so. I was presently invited to Supper, I promised, and went. No sooner was I there, but who should come
in, but the old Fryar, scantly able to goe for Age,Ecce intrat Frater senex, Silicernium, gravis. Puer à tergo sequitur cum codicibus. a Boy behinde him, loaden with Bookes. I eftsoones perceiued, that now I was to looke about mee. Downe we sate, and least any time should be lost, my Friend that had invited me, presently proposeth the foresaid Question, the Fryar makes answer, as before hee had preached. I was silent, for willingly I keepe my Selfe out of all such strouglings as are odious, and vnfruitfull. At length they asked what my Opinion was; and then when in good Manners I could bee silent no longer, I answered what I thought, but in very few Words, and somewhat carelesly. Here the Fryar began a fresh, and with a long premeditated Speech, which might haue seru'd for Two Sermons at the least, barked, & brawled all Supper-time.Summa Rationum tota pendebat à Miraculu, quorum nobis effutiebat iam è Mariali malta, tum quadam ex alijs e
• usdem for • e Libellus. The Summa totalis of his Reasons depended vpon the Miracles which hee brought vs out of his Mary-Booke, and some other Miracles out of some other Bookes, which he willed to be brought to the Table, to giue the greater authority to his Speeches. When at length he had made an end, I modestly began to answere: First, that in all that long Processe hee had said just nothing, whereby such might be perswaded, if any happely were present, that would not admit of those Miracles, and that might very well bee, and their Faith in Christ firme ynough. Which Miracles besides, had they bene most vndoubtedly true, yet to prooue the Matter in Question, they had no force, nor strength at all. For though you may easily finde a Prince, that at the Intreaties of his Mother, may sometimes forgiue his Enemies some what: so
there is no Prince againe so foolish, that will make a Law, promising impunity to Traitours, that shall perfourme some certaine Offices to his Mother, therby to make them the more audacious against himselfe. ManyMultis vltro citro{que} dictis effeci tandem, vt ille tolleretur laudibus, ipse pro Stulto riderer. words spent to & fro, at length it came to this passe, that the Fryar was mightily extolled, and my selfe laught at for a Foole. Nay, the Matter came to that passe, by the depraued Disposition of Men, that vnder the colour of Piety, fauoured their owne Faults, that that Opinion could hardly bee repressed, though the Bishop himselfe of that City vsed all the meanes he possibly could.

18. I should here tell you of an other Psalter, that which our Adversaries name IESVS PSALTER, for that they haue to, and all because forsooth the Name of Iesus is so often therein. But leauing our Ladies Psalter, and Iesus Psalter, whereofSee my L. of CANTER. on Ionas, Lect. 18. §. 5. Others more copiously, I come to the true Psalter indeed, DAVIDS PSALTER, or DAVIDS PSALMES, hauing that of Hieron. Apol. advers. Joui • . S. Ierom continually in mine Eye,

epigraph.q: COMMENTATORIS officium est, non quid ipse velit: sed quid sentiat ille quem interpretatur exponere. Alioqui si contraria dixerit: non tam INTERPRES erit, quàm ADVERSARIVS eius, quem nititur explanare.

div.head: PSAL. I. Beatus Vir.

q.p: 1 BLessed is the man that hath not walked in the Counsel of the Vngodly, nor stand in the way of sinners, and hath not sit in the seate of the scornfull.
2 But his delight is in the Law of the Lord: and in his Law will he exercise himselfe day and night.
3 And he shall be like a Tree planted by the water side that will bring forth his fruit in due season.
4 His leaf also shall not wither: and looke whatsoeuer he doth it shall prosper.
5 As for the Vngodly it is not so with them: but they are like the Chaff, which the wind scattereth away from the face of the earth.
6 Therefore the Vngodly shall not be able to stand in the iudgement: neither the Sinners in the Congregation of the Righteous.
7 But the Lord knoweth the way of the Righteous: and the way of the Vngodly shall perish.

div.head: THE ANALYSIS.
div.p:
THis First and Formost Psalme, be it but an Introduction to the rest, as some will haue it; or a Psalme it selfe, and one of the rest, as all in a manner are of opinion, certaine it is, that as it yeelds vs good Instruction, so was
it framed to that purpose. In the which the Psalmist endeauouring to describe the Felicity of the Godly, he both prôposeth vnto vs, and ôpposeth betweene themselues, the Godly, and the Wicked. Concerning the Godly he declares vnto vs their Condition, & their Reward. Their Condition, in that abhorring Impiety, as it is in the First Verse, they follow religious courses, as it is in the Second: Their Reward, in that they participate of the manifold Blessings of God, as the same Blessings are intimated to vs in the Third, and Fourth Verses. Concerning the Wicked he proclaymes vnto vs both their State, & their End. their State in the Fift Verse, their End, in the Sixt, which State, and End of theirs to be most miserable, he prooueth from the Day of Iudgement, and that in the Seauenth and last Verse.

And thus much briefly of theConcerning this Analysis, as also all the rest, they are for the most part taken out of Huldericus Herlinus his Analises Synopticae printed 1603. Analysis, or Resolution of the whole Psalme into those severall Parts, whereof it doth consist. Come we now to the word • themselues verse by verse, and let vs rub them as S. Austen Aug. de Verb. Dom. Ser. 14. speakes, like Eares of Corne in our hand, Vt ad latentia grana perveniamus, that so we may come to the wheat that lies hid in those words, as it were in the husk.

VErs. 1. Blessed is the Man that hath not walked in the counsel of the Vngodly, nor stand in the way of Sinners, and hath not sit in the seate of the Scornfull.] It was Pindarus his
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Pind. Od. 6. obseruation, that in beginning any worke, the Forefront thereof should bee made glittering and glorious. And I may truely say of this First Psalme whether we respect the Psalme in generall, or the very first word of it in particular, it is most glittering, most glorious. Blessed is the Man! Quàm aptum, quàm opportunum principium, Ambros. in hunc. Psal. saith St Ambrose, how meet and convenient a beginning. For as they, saith he, that take vpon them to exhibit Games, are wont to propose a Reward, and the Excellency
of a Crowne, that they which come to the Games may striue the more earnestly to obtaine the same, so our Lord Iesus Christ hath proposed the Glory of an heauenly Kingdome, the benefit of perpetuall Rest, the Blessednesse of eternall Life to the best endeauours of men. And as a Generall, saith he, going to warfar, promiseth a Donatiue to the Souldier, and Promotions to his Captaines, Vt spes commodi furetur laborem, & motum abscondat periculi: that the hope of gaine may both steale away their labour from them, and hide and conceale the feare of any danger that may betide them: so Dauid as the Herald of that great Generall, exhorteth the Souldiers, calls the Combatants to the Lists, and proposeth the Reward in these words, Blessed is the Man which hath not walked in the Counsel of the Vngodly. A Pramio coepit, vt pondus futuri certaminis eleuaret. He begins with the Reward to make the burthen of that which they should afterwards endure the lighter. He proposeth the wages that every man leaping over in his heart the troubles and vexations of these present worldly affaires, should contend with most speedy desire to the happinesse of things to come. Blessed, saith he, is the Man: and what could more be giuen to Man then which nothing greater by the Apostle himselfe could be giuen vnto God. For God is called by the1. Tim. 6.15. Apostle the Blessed, and only potentat • , and King of Kings, and Lord of Lords; Bea • itudinis tamen non supergreditur potestatem, and yet for all that, God goes not beyond the preheminence of blessednes. Now this word BLESSED as it is the first word, and auspicious beginning of this First Psalme, so is it likewise of Fine more which begin with the selfe same word, as,Ps. 32.1. BLESSED is he whose vnrighteousnesse is forgiuen, and whose sinne is covered. Ps. 41.1. BLESSED is be th •• considereth the poore and needy. Ps. 112.1. BLESSED is the man that feareth the Lord. Ps. 119.1. BLESSED are those that are vndefiled in the way, and walke in the Law of the Lord. 1 Ps. 128.1. BLESSED are all they
that feare the Lord, and walke in his waies. But whereas in the English, the word BLESSED is still an Adiectiue, in the Hebrew both here in this Psalme, as also in the rest, it is alwaies, A • HKE, Blessings, or Beatitudes, not only a Substantiue and in the Abstract, but also in the plurall nomber.

First for the Abstract, it sheweth that they are Blessings Substantiall, subsisting by themselues, and that it is much more significant so to speake, then to call a Man Blessed by the Adiectiue onely.So the Poet, Non vitiosus homo es Zoile sed vitium. Martiall. l. 11. Epig. 93. Like as the Apostle speaking of our Saviour, and vs, vseth the Abstract, not the Concrete, the Substantiue, not the Adiectiue; in both:2. Cor. 5.21. He hath made him to be Sinne for vs, who knewe no sinne, that we might be made the Righteousnesse of God in him. He saith not Sinfull, or Righteous; but Sinne, and Righteousnesse.

The Plurall sheweth an heap of Blessings that betyde such a man, not as Esaw Gen. 27.38. said to Isaac, Hast thou but one blessing my Father? No: but as Leah in an other case, A troupe Gen. 30.11. saith she, commeth, and she called his name, Gad. For what is Blessednes indeed, but a troupe or company of Blessings, intimated by the1 Cor. 2.9. Apostle in his first Epistle to the Corinthians, and specified byDeut 2.3. Moses in his Book of Deuteronomy. Some make it to consist of the Goods of the Body, the Goods of the Mynd, and of externall and outward Goods, but our Sauiour flyes a farre higher pitch. For, beginning his Sermon on the Mount withMat. 5.3, Blessed are the pure in spirit, for theirs is the kingdome of heauen; he addeth thereunto, Blessed are they that mourne, for they shall be comforted; Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth; Blessed are they that doe hunger and thirst after Righteousnes, for they shall be filled: Blessed are the mercifull, for they shall obtaine mercy; Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God: Blessed are the Peacemakers, for they shall be called the Children of God; and lastly, to shew that where Blessednes ends, there it doth as
it were begin againe, Blessed are they faith he, that are persequuted for Righteousnes sake, for theirs is the kingdome of heauen: so that à primo ad vltimum: there is in this Blessednes, first the kingdome of heauen; secondly, all comfort; thirdly, inheriting the earth; fourthly, a filling full, or fully satisfying; fiftly, obtayning mercy; sixtly, a seeing of God; seauenthly, aMulti in Imperio Romano sunt, sed maiorem Imperii gratiam, qui propiores Imperatori sunt, consequuntur. Ambros. sup. Luc. l. 5. c. 13. neerer tye vnto him, as namely to be called the Children of God; rightly and lastly, to begin againe, and to haue in propriety and perpetility, the kingdome of heauen. Incrementa Virtutum, Incrementa Praemiorum: the augmentation of Vertues,Ambros. Ib. saith St Ambrose, is the augmentation of Rewards, Plus est enim Des esse Filium, quàm possidere terram, & consolationem mereri. For more it is to be the Child of God, then to possesse the earth, and to be comforted.

But what? is Man only? is not Woman blessed to? Yes doubtles; for the word Man includeth both. Hominis appellatione tam foeminam quam masculum contineri non dubitatur. There is no doubtDe Verb. significat. nu. 152. sayth the Ciuil Law, but this word Homo compriseth the Female, aswell as the Male; and, Ʋiris & Multeribus commune nomen Homo. Homo Clem. Alex. 〈…〉 . 4. sayth Clemens Alexandrinus, is a common Name to Men and Women both. And if so be reply be made, that the word in the vulgar is not Homo, but Vir, and in the Greeke, not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , (about which two Greeke words wasVid. Act. & Mon. edit. 4. p. 1456. col. 2. once no small adoe, concerning Women • receiuing the Communion.) Saint Am • rose Ambros. in hunc Ps. replyes againe, that by the word Ʋir, 2 Woman may be vnderstood to, In Homine signatur vter{que} in Viro soxus exprimitur. Sed quemadmodum cum Homo dicitur, vter{que} comprehend • euro • a cum Vir nominatur, & mulier cuius Virille, fit, intolligit •• . And going on in the same place; Besides that their Nature being one sayth he, their operations must not be severed, and whose worke is equ ••• , their reward must be equall to. Like to thisBas. in hunc Ps. hath St Basil, The Creation of Man and W ••• n were both alike,
therefore their wages and hyre must be both alike to.

Man and Woman then being both of them capable of Blessednes, you will happely demaund what Man? what Woman? The word Man is here indefinite, and signifieth not this, or that Man, this, or that Woman in particular, but any, or euery Man, any, or euery Woman, as the Indefinite signifieth generally throughout the Scripture. And therefore that saying of Moses, Deut. 27.26. Cursed is h •
(or, cursed is the Man) that confirmeth not all the words of this Law to doe them: the Apostle Saint Paul expounding that place, Cursed is euery one Gal. 3.10. sayth hee, that continueth not in all things which are written in the Booke of the Law to do them. Now what Men, and what Women thus are blessed, wee shall see by and by, in the meane time let vs consider why the time present is here vsed, seeing Blessednes is to bee hereafter, and yet the Prophet here sayth, Blessed is the Man.

It is an vndoubted trueth, there is no Felicity in this World; he that thinks of a Worldly Happines, erres as farre as the World is wyde. In the World Ioh. 16.33. sayth our Sauiour, ye shall haue tribulation, and yet to sweeten those words againe, Be of good cheere, sayth he, I haue ouercome the World. Non armatomilita, sed i • risa cruce, not by meanes of men at armesAug. in Psal. 62. sayth St Austen, but by meanes of my Crosse that was scorned at by men at armes; and as himselfe led the way in this case, so must euery one of his, endeauour to follow him. Now for euery one in this his following, is assured that at the length, it shall be happy with him hereafter, being a member of that Body, whose Head Christ Iesus hath passed the waues of this world; hence it is that his Blessednes being thus begunne in this World, he is styled already Blessed, for he tends to that Blessednes hereafter. Like as the Apostle St Paul, Our Conuersation is in heauen Philip. 3.20. sayth he, when yet the Apostle, and his Philippians were still vpon earth. Indeed we haue here the Pledge of Happines, or rather the Earnest
thereof. For asAug. de Verb. Apost, ser. 13. St Austen very wittily, When a thing is restored, the Pledge is taken away, but the Earnest is part of the bargayne, which shall neuer be taken away: so is it in this case, Nescit naufragia, qui semperin porru tranquillitaris est. Come what come can, he cannot make ShipwrackAmbros. de Iacob, & vita beata c. 6. sayth St Ambrose, that is alwayes in a quiet harbour, the same in effect that our Sauiour Mat. 7.25. saith of the wise Man that built his house vpon a Rock. But now let vs see what Men, and what Women are thus Blessed, or rather what Man, or what Woman: That hath not walked in the Counsel of the Vngodly, nor stand in the way of Sinners: and hath not sit in the seat of the Scorneful.

First for the word Stand vsed here in the Praeterperfect tence, as also in the Praeterpluperfect in an other Psalme, where it isPs. 106.23. said, He would haue destroyed them had not Moses his chosen stand before him in the gap, whereas we in these dayes would haue said stood in both places, I cannot but think that it is the phrase of speaking in some of our Shires here in England, in regard that Mr Fox also a moderne wrighter to speake of, doth so vse the word. Speaking of B. Gardiner, Such a platforme Act. & Mon, p. 1787. col. 2. sayth he, to build his Popery vpon, as he thought should haue stand for euer, and a day. I once thought it to be the old English, for that old Heywood so Heywood Epig. vpon Proverb. Epig. 67. New broome sweepeth cleane, which is thus vnderstand: New broome sweepeth cleane in the cleane sweepers hand. vseth it, in one of his Epigrams, though it be in the Present tence Passiue that he so vseth it, and in the word Vnderstand; but hauing seene in our great Library an old Manuscript of the Psalmes in English, that vseth the word Stood, I was contented to stand no longer in that opinion. But from Words let vs come to Matter.

There is in these words a threefold Gradation, or as it were three Degrees. First of Persons; Secondly of Actions; Thirdly of the Objects of those Actions. The three Degrees of Persons, are the Vngodly, Sinners, and Scornefull; the three Degrees of Actions, are Walking, Standing, and Sitting; the three Degrees of Objects, are Counsel,
Way, and Seat. By the Persons are implyed all the wicked whôsoeuer; by the Actions all correspondence with them whâtsoeuer; by the Obiects, all iniquity & impiety committed, hôwsoeuer. Concerning the Persons, no man at first dash in the Superlatiue degree of being wicked. Nemo repentè fuit turpissimus Iuvenal. Sat. 2. sayth the Poet, no man in a tryce as bad as bad may be. Euen good Emperors, as the Emperor Traian Procul differre cunctos Principes Neronis quinquennio. Sex. Aurel. Vict. de Caesar. in Neron. obserued, came farre short of Nero • s first fiue yeeres, and he who when Offenders were to be condemned, wished so solemly that he could not aSenec. de Clem. l. 2. c. 1. letter on the Booke, how shamefully did he afterwards murther his owne Mother.
